page.title: 02 Hornby in the Past.
page.content: Once Hornby was engaged in the mining of coal. The old Toll House (now a petrol station) 2 km. South of the village marks the boundary of the coal field. Hornby has retained its feudal-style appearance;houses which once belonged to tenants and estate workers,together with the parish church and the Castle Hotel, which was once the local coaching inn, are clustered below the hilltop castle. At the Northern end of the village is Castlestede, said to be the best example of a Motte and Bailey in the county and the suggested site of the original castle in Hornby, built by Horn, a Saxon chief, after whom the village takes its name. Today, few inhabitants work in the village. Most people commute to their place of work.
